awd_titl_txt: Investigating Approximate Number System Computation in Children
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates children's capacity for arithmetic computation without symbols or formal notation, before they encounter formal mathematics training in school. The Approximate Number System (ANS), a cognitive system which is operational from early infancy onward, allows humans to approximately quantify sets of items without language or symbols. Research suggests that the ANS could potentially support arithmetic operations, such as addition and subtraction, and that the ANS could therefore serve as a bridge to learning formal mathematics. However, the arithmetic capacity of the ANS, and how this capacity develops, is not well understood. This project fills that knowledge gap by systematically examining the computational capacity of the ANS using a series of experiments designed to assess young children before they learn the formal rules of arithmetic in school. The project addresses theoretical debates about the early cognitive architecture of the ANS and its role in arithmetic computation. The project will identify potential ways that educators could leverage children's pre-symbolic mathematical intuitions in order to help them learn formal mathematics. This has implications for STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) education. 

This project will examine the degree to which computations performed over ANS representations parallel true arithmetic computations.  The development of the computational capacity of the ANS will be examined.  Symbolic arithmetic computation obeys a set of functional rules. For example, the result of an arithmetic computation like 5+6 is a new, independent quantity that is just as precise as the quantities it was derived from, and which can be manipulated and used in further computations. These functional rules make symbolic arithmetic computation both powerful and flexible. This project aims to identify the functional rules of non-symbolic arithmetic with the ANS. In a series of experiments, four to six year-old children will be asked to solve non-symbolic problems with unknown addends (e.g., 5+__=11). This task requires children to perform arithmetic-like computation, holding two separate ANS representations in mind (e.g. approximately five and approximately 11) and performing a computation over them (e.g. subtracting approximately five from approximately 11) to derive a solution. Each experiment is aimed at examining different components of the functional rules of non-symbolic arithmetic, including the representational structure and precision of the solutions to ANS computations and the extent to which these solutions can be used in further computations. Additional measures of working memory capacity, symbolic math performance, and ANS representational precision are used to elucidate contributions of these cognitive systems to the computational capacity and development of the ANS. Data will be analyzed using a combination of traditional null hypothesis significance testing, Bayes factor analysis, and logistic regression. The project will therefore compliment what is known about the representational structure of the ANS by shedding light on its computational architecture and the development of this architecture in early childhood.

por.por_cntn:
The Approximate Number System (ANS) is a cognitive system which allows us to approximately quantify sets of items without language or symbols. The ANS is operational starting in infancy, and supports our ability to estimate the size of an audience at a concert, or to say whether one flock of birds is more numerous than another, without counting each individual.

Before children learn how to do formal arithmetic, like addition and subtraction, they can intuitively perform arithmetic-like computations on ANS representations. For example, if children see a set of objects, and then another set of objects, they can estimate the total of the two sets together, effectively adding the two quantities without counting or doing exact, paper-and-pencil addition. Because the ANS is early-developing and supports non-symbolic quantification, it had been suggested that the ANS may serve as a wedge into learning formal mathematics for young children who are just entering school. However, the mechanisms by which the ANS performs arithmetic-like operations were not well understood, making it difficult to gauge the utility of leveraging the ANS to develop mathematics interventions.

This project examined the computational capacity of the ANS in young children. Specifically, we investigated whether ANS computations showed two crucial computational hallmarks of formal arithmetic: consistent precision (the outputs of computations are as precise as the inputs) and functional flexibility (the outputs of computations can be used as inputs into other computations). We also investigated how ANS computational capacity develops during the preschool years.

We found that, in young children, ANS computation lacked both computational hallmarks of formal arithmetic. First, we found that when children perform computations over ANS representations, their solutions are less precise than when they are simply asked to hold ANS representations in mind without performing computations. We also found that the development of the precision of different computations followed different trajectories in childhood: while children became more adept with addition over ANS representations with increasing age, their ability to perform unknown-addend operations underwent more protracted development. Second, we found that when children perform computations with the ANS, they are unable to use the solutions as inputs into other ANS computations, and this limit was consistent across development even as children's ANS computations became more precise.

Together, our results suggest important limitations on children's early intuitive arithmetic abilities. While ANS computations may bear some surface similarity to symbolic arithmetic computation, ANS computations are algorithmically distinct in crucial ways. Our results advance our understanding of the capacity and development of this early, foundational cognitive process.

Our results also can be used to improve early STEM education. Modern math education guidelines suggest that educators should help children apply their intuitions about computation to acquire formal skill. Because the ANS is early-developing, researchers have eyed it as a potential support for formal learning. However, our research suggests that the ANS may not be the most fruitful inroad to learning formal math because it is operationally limited and algorithmically distinct from formal computation. We expect that the results of our research can be used by researchers and practitioners in early childhood education to better target mathematics interventions and learning materials to take optimal advantage of children's early non-symbolic capacities.

In addition to our primary research goals, our studies also included several additional measures of general cognitive capacities, allowing us to investigate the development of children's working memory abilities in addition to their ANS computational capacity. We found that children's ability to track and update information stored in working memory, and their ability to use an adult-like working memory strategy, increased significantly across our age range, contributing to our understanding of the development of this crucial cognitive capacity.

This project also had benefits for participating families and students. Children and their families participated in the research at a local science museum and (during the COVID-19 pandemic) from their homes via videoconferencing. Our team interacted with hundreds of families with young children, who were able to participate first-hand in the scientific process. These families received educational information on children's early numerical abilities and evidence-based activities to do at home. Our team included undergraduate students from backgrounds that are underrepresented in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics), who received hands-on training in conducting rigorous and ethical scientific research.
